metadata.title: The martingale betting system in roulette | by Markus Rene Pae | Towards Data Science
metadata.h1: The martingale betting system in roulette
metadata.description: Quite recently, I stumbled upon a Facebook ad that said: “Make money easily from home | net wage €7000 per month”. Since my current salary is way below that, I got curious. Only a fool would say no…

all_paragraphs: Quite recently, I stumbled upon a Facebook ad that said: “Make money easily from home | net wage €7000 per month”. Since my current salary is way below that, I got curious. Only a fool would say no to this, right?

Not only did they offer a higher salary, but flexible working hours were also on the table: basically for each hour, the expected revenue would be 50 euros. Many aspects made me think that this is a legitimate thing, such as:

Without googling it first, I signed up and began with my training. It took maybe 3–5 minutes until I realized that this is all about systematic betting on roulette. I’ve had some Facebook ads about it a few years back and every time I try to see through the strategy itself. Mostly it is about a simple casino game (such as roulette) and a martingale betting system.
In roulette, it is always possible to place a bet on something that has a 50% chance of occurring: even/odd number, red/black tile, 1–18/19–36. The martingale system is as follows:

You should start with a small amount, for instance, 1€, and keep making the same bet until you lose. When this happens, double the size of your bet (2€) for the next spin. If you win, then you will recover the money you lost on the previous round and win a little extra. If you stay on the losing course, just keep doubling your bet and the logic stays the same — for example, if you have lost 7 consecutive times (which is equivalent to losing 127€), then your next win of 128€ should mean that you haven’t lost anything at all. Keep in mind that as soon as you win, you should restart and make the 1€ bet again for the next spin and repeat the entire process.
There may be two different, yet popular opinions on this:
You can never lose all your money, as long as you have infinite amount of money.
It is impossible in roulette to lose 10 times straight when placing the same bet.

In my honest opinion, you can’t have an infinite amount of money and it is possible to lose more than 10 times in a row when placing the same bet (in fact it should have a probability just below 0,1%). To prove that, I have made some simulations using Python and here are the results.
I swear by the name of Science that the evidence I shall give shall be the truth, the whole truth, and nothing but the truth.

The script simulates 1000000 roulette outcomes within a second. At each simulation, a random whole number between 1 and 36 is picked. I have intentionally dropped 0 to lose the house edge. Hence we have a 50% chance of “winning” instead of 48,6% or 47,4%, depending on the roulette wheel you are playing.
Each result is later stored in a list called results and that’s what we should analyze next. Let’s add another layer of code:

This takes the results list we created before and creates another list where numbers are replaced with “odd” and “even”, depending on their value. The contents of resultscopy should look like this [“odd”, “even”, “even”, “even”, “odd”, “odd”].
Now we should explore this list while counting the amount of “odd” and “even” we could consecutively get.
This function iterates over the list containing odds and evens and counts the consecutive results. In this way, a list of:
since there were two odd numbers at first, then one even number, then four odd numbers, and so on… Let’s add a bit more to our code to obtain readable statistics:
This creates a dictionary and counts the amount of odd- or even-streaks that occurred during 1,000,000 simulations. The results are fascinating:

When playing roulette 1,000,000 times in a row, it is possible to have 19 outcomes in a row that are the same. Imagine using the martingale system described above and losing 19 times in a row. Your 20th bet would have to be 524,288 times larger than your smallest bet. Can you afford that?
Note: In such extreme cases, table limits stop players from making bets that are astronomically high and hence the martingale strategy fails after a certain number of consecutive losses.

Let’s add a few steps and suppose we have money in this simulation. The smallest bet is 1€ and the average Joe starts playing with 500€. In python, we should add a few global variables and redefine our oddeven() function.
In an ideal world, you would never expect your money to get below 0. Let’s run 1,000,000 simulations and plot the amount of money we would have after each game.
Oh no! There seem to be three extreme spikes indicating that our money went below zero.

It was mentioned before that the martingale system works perfectly if you have tons of money (or an infinite amount of money). It is true if one can define such an amount. Before writing this article, one of my simulations showed a losing streak of 25 — you would need 33,5 million to recover from that on your 26th bet. I believe that most of the readers wouldn’t have the nerve to even place that bet.

If you are wondering if I’m showing a result that I got after a few tries, then yes. I tried to get the best figure I could get in a few tries, but I can guarantee you that every time the script was executed, the average Joe went bankrupt. I added some extra code to have a notion of how this simulation went: “Fault” if the amount of money went below 0 and “Success” if it never happened:
To run this script multiple times (in this case 100 times), a batch file was created:
100 executions of 1,000,000 roulette simulations took my computer a little less than two minutes. Out of these 100, none were successful.

What if we modify those parameters a bit? Let’s say our average Joe has 5000 euros in the beginning and is determined to play 1000 games per day for a week (7000 games in total). And to be extra sure, let’s execute it 10 times and present the results in a tabular form:
As you can already see, with these settings, an average Joe would have a ~66% chance to have some money remaining at the end of the week, and the highest possible revenue would be around 3600€.

Using a martingale betting system in roulette can destroy your wallet and therefore it would be wise to avoid it in the first place. There’s indeed a correlation between the initial amount of money, success percentage and number of games one is willing to play. Nevertheless, if something has a 1:1000 chance of occurring, it can happen on 1st, 1000th, 2000th try. You just simply don’t know, when.
Keep in mind that the house edge was intentionally ignored. In real life, you’d have it working against you.
